JUDGES: Karel Jungwiert;Mark Villiger;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicants , Mr PERSON and PERSON , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in Coscalia . They are represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

The applicants’ son PERSON was born in DATE . On DATE he was remanded in custody by ORG on the suspicion of burglary . He was transferred to the PERSON prison where he was placed in a single cell . TIME , at TIME , he was found dead in his cell , strangled with his shoelaces .

Following a police investigation , in which neither the applicants nor apparently the NORP consular authorities were involved , the NORP authorities concluded on the basis of a post - mortem that the ORG son had committed suicide and discontinued the criminal investigation into his death . On DATE the NORP authorities informed the NORP consular authorities in a note verbale about the outcome of the proceedings .
On DATE counsel for the applicants requested that the criminal investigation into their son ’s death be reopened .
On DATE ORG refused on the grounds that the applicants had not identified a specific suspect responsible for their son ’s death .
Upon counsel ’s motion for reconsideration the criminal proceedings against an unidentified suspect were reopened and , on DATE , again discontinued .
On DATE ORG refused the applicants’ request to order that the investigation be reopened .

On DATE ORG dismissed as inadmissible the applicants’ request for a decision concerning the discontinuance of the criminal investigation into their son ’s death . ORG held that the applicants had failed to name an individual suspect in respect of the alleged manslaughter as required by the relevant provisions of LAW and noted as “ merely supplementary ” that the applicants had failed to provide all the facts and pieces of evidence as required by law ( compare “ Relevant domestic law and practice ” below ) . The decision was served on the NORP counsel on CARDINAL DATE .

If a criminal investigation offers sufficient reasons for preferring public charges , the Public Prosecutor shall prefer them by submitting a bill of indictment to the competent court ( LAW ) of LAW ) . In all other cases the Public Prosecutor shall terminate the proceedings ( Article CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .

An aggrieved party may not prefer public charges concerning felonies and serious misdemeanours . If ORG orders a criminal investigation to be discontinued the aggrieved party may , however , complain to ORG within DATE ( Article CARDINAL ) of the Code of Criminal Procedure ) . If ORG dismisses the complaint , the aggrieved party may apply for a decision of ORG ordering ORG to prefer charges ( LAW ) by a bill of indictment that must include the indicted person , the criminal offence with which the person is charged , the time and place of its commission , its elements of crime and the statutory elements which are to applied ( LAW ) . The application for such a decision by ORG must contain all the information in a comprehensive manner needed by ORG to assess whether criminal charges ought to be preferred . ORG decides on the basis of the application without consulting the investigation file .

According to the case - law of ORG an application that ORG be ordered to prefer public charges must contain the name of a specific suspect . Only exceptionally may ORG be ordered to open criminal proceedings against unknown persons PERSON ( see ORG , no . CARDINAL Ws DATE , CARDINAL DATE ) .
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Basic PERSON reads as follows :
“ Human dignity shall be inviolable . To respect and protect it shall be the duty of all state authority . ”
Article CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , in so far as relevant , provides that every person shall have the right to life and physical integrity .

ORG has , inter alia , jurisdiction to hear constitutional complaints , which may be filed by any person alleging that CARDINAL of his basic rights has been infringed by a public authority ( Article PERSON ) ( CARDINAL ) of LAW , and LAW on ORG ) .

A constitutional complaint is , as far as relevant here , only admissible after the exhaustion of all other legal remedies ( Article CARDINAL ) of ORG ) . The complaints before ORG must therefore have been presented – at least in substance – to the relevant courts in conformity with the applicable formal requirements .

ORG has on several occasions quashed decisions of ORG dismissing applications that criminal proceedings be continued on the grounds that a too formalistic handling of the admissibility criteria had resulted in a violation of the applicants’ right of access to a court ( see ORG , no .
